column8: See your friend circle la kawan. Those who hate umno automatically will hate hadi. I dont see he is pro umno, for me he is moderate. He do condemn ummo. What will he get if he make enemy with DAP n UMNO.

When you're revered enough, you don't need an official title. There is no doubt that PAS as a whole wants 'Islam #1' agenda as a whole, Nik Aziz did not oppose that. Yes, he was quite extreme at various points in PAS history (wanting age limits on snooker for example), but he was also a realist. He opposed UMNO's racial politics and later on (perhaps too late) he understood that defeating BN first should take priority. Only after sustained wins against BN could PAS could put a realistic plan for their Islamic vision.A reason most opposition supporters are sore at PAS now is because PAS has seemingly given up the idea of defeating UMNO. Rather, the new PAS is willing to go in bed with UMNO to get a bigger say in Malay politics. Just like how UMNO said they don't need the minorities, so is PAS saying that they don't need the opposition to influence Muslim policies anymore, especially since there are so many elements within UMNO who are using the religious tactics willingly.

Would DAP give up its principles in order to prevent 3 sided contests in the next GE?  Answer is a clear no.  It would not remain in a coalition with a party  that pushes only its own agenda.  Besides that, lets not forget that PAS decided to sever ties with DAP but insisted on remaining in PR.  What sort of "marriage" is that?    The marriage was already on the rocks.  Better to quit.  IMO, all 3 parties had some blame in the break up of the marriage/coalition.  Screaming PAS might be in the same card with BN?  PAS does seem to share more commonalities with UMNO these days than to PKR and DAP.  You can't see that?  Yes, already divorced.  Marriage is over.  But now there is a new 3 party marriage.  Amanah, PKR and DAP.  All 3 share a common agenda.    If PAS shares the common agenda of these 3 parties and puts aside its own agenda, it is welcome to join the new coalition.  PAS shouldn't join this new coalition if it aims to purse its own agendas after utilizing the coalition to come into power.  The invitation was sent but it was not accepted.  So move on already.  Still want to score brownie points for what?

PKR could've easily sided with PAS and formed another Pakatan with PAS but they chose to go with DAP instead. They're the kingmaker because their seats added to either one side would've formed the majority in Pakatan.Not inviting someone to join a new coalition is not the same as kicking someone out of the existing coalition. It's not right to blame 1 out of 3 parties in the coalition, especially when it was PKR that triggered the break up via Langkah Kajang.

column7: From: KL
column8: even if the 10-15 seats is the difference between getting putrajaya or not?the thing about being a third force party is that you dont need to have a large amount of seats - you only need to get enough seats to make the other sides want you in their camp. the coming election may be a close one, and antagonising pas could very well doom the campaign. imagine if the deficit was only 7 seats? everyone knows that pas' agenda has consistent been a religious one - its an islamist party after all. it has been so since the merdeka times. it's not a surprise to anyone that the non-fit will cause a friction.even then, the opposition parties have repeatedly coalitioned together - principles or no principles - throughout the past twenty years. every time someone raised a voice about the absolute contrast between their underlying objectives, it was met with either derision or 'let's win putrajaya first'. in this, both sides have put 'principles' in the backseat. the leadership isnt stupid as to not see where the whole thing will end up yet (repeatedly) sought to ally with each other. i say this because this is politics, and political expediency is the name of the game. you say its a divorce but we've been through this many times before and everytime the chorus is the same - one slogan when we're together, the other slogan when we're apart. in between dap and pas followers insult each other and cause so much strife. im just saying to look at history and realise that the door is never closed. politicians mudah lupa, and political followers remember only as far as their leaders do. im only concerned that the rancour this politicking is generating undermines the spirit of the country, especially when the spite (on both sides) involve religious and ethnic perspectives. country comes before party.
